provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold by Tatham to the British Museum in Oct. 1867.

objnote.p: This is one of seven monochrome wash drawings (Objects 37-43) by Blake of figures painted by Michelangelo in the Sistine Chapel. They were very probably copied from the engravings of Adamo Ghisi, after drawings by Giorgio Ghisi, published in *Pitture dipinte nella Volta della Capella Sistina nel Vaticano* (1773).
Frederick Tatham added a pen and ink inscription in the lower right corner of the leaf bearing this wash drawing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This wash drawing after Michelangelo shows the biblical figure Daniel with two smaller figures. In the drawing's center, Daniel sits on a low step or platform in the corner of a room with bare walls and a bare floor. Daniel has short, wavy hair and wears many layers of clothing: a long gown, a cape over his shoulders, and a fringed piece of draping cloth over his legs. Daniel sits with his knees bent and spread. His right leg is drawn up near to his body, and his right foot rests on the ground at the base of the step on which he sits. Daniel's left leg bends outward and extends forward, toward the viewer, and his prominent left foot rests on the ground at the lower edge of the drawing (which curves inward at the edges). Daniel's body faces the viewer but bends leftward at the waist, leaning to the side and dropping his right shoulder as he writes on a tablet next to him. The tablet is angled away from Daniel and rests on a stand. The upper portion of the stand is triangular in shape and is supported by a smaller rectangular piece, leaving an open area near Daniel's cape. In that empty space is a small scroll. On the left side of the stand, some other object is attached. It may provide storage for writing utensils. Daniel's right forearm extends outward along the tablet, and he grasps a quill or other implement as he writes near the top of the tablet. Daniel's head leans toward this tablet and tilts downward, but he does not appear to look at the tablet but instead at the ground. His eyes may even be closed. His mouth may be open. Daniel's left arm extends forward and to the right, bending sharply at the wrist. His left hand rests on the edge of another tablet; his index and middle fingers point downward. This second tablet is much larger than the first. It rests in Daniel's lap and leans out ward from him (toward the viewer). Beneath this tablet, perhaps hanging on it or supporting it, is a nude male child. This child, much smaller than Daniel, faces forward and to the left. His right leg nearly straightens as his foot rests on the ground near Daniel's right foot. The child's left leg bends inward, and his right foot is hidden behind the draping of Daniel's gown. The child's genitals appear between his slightly spread legs. He bends forward as if holding the tablet on his back. The child's right arm bends sharply as his elbow rises into the air beside his head and his right hand reaches toward his back. The child's left arm reaches upward, and he grasps the edge of the tablet with his left hand. His head lowers, and his eyes close. The child has short hair. A second child appears above Daniel's left shoulder. Now absent from Michelangelo's fresco, this child is almost entirely covered by a large cloak which extends from Daniel's neck at left to his elbow at right. The child faces the viewer and leans forward but looks to the left, perhaps toward Daniel's writing. The child's gender is uncertain. The left wall and rise of the step or platform are shaded; shadows appear at right of Daniel's neck and in the lower right-hand corner of the drawing beneath the larger tablet and Daniel's left leg.
